LOVELAND PRODUCTS INC.
AMMONIA PROCESS

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Risk Management Plan

40 CFR 68.155(a)    The Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response
                        Policies at the Stationary Source

The stationary source covered by this Risk Management Plan is the Loveland Products Inc. (LPI)Ammonia Process.  LPI is a micronutrient manufacturing facility located in Fairbury, Nebraska.  LPI maintains all of the equipment in its process by employing the best engineering practices in the industry.  LPI strives for excellence in the facility operations and for full compliance with all local, state, and federal laws and regulations.

Meeting environmental regulations is part of LPI's policies and by developing and maintaining this Risk Management Program, LPI is complying with the Federal Accidental Prevention Provisions (40 CFR Part 68).  LPI is committed to the accidental release prevention program.

LPI maintains a thorough detailed Emergency Response Plan designed specifically for an ammonia release for the Ammonia Process.  The plan will be reviewed with response organizations and others.

40 CFR 68.155(b)    The Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled

The LPI Ammonia Process produces a fertilizer solution by blending water, anhydrous ammonia, acetic acid, and a variety of heavy metals in two low pressure mix tanks.  The primary function of the anhydrous ammonia is to raise the pH of the fertilizer solution.
Liquid anhydrous ammonia is stored in a 30,000 gallon (150,000 pound) pressure vessel under ambient temperature.  The pressure vessel has a maximum fill level of 85% resulting in a maximum storage capacity of 25,000 gallons or 125,000 pounds.   The pressure vessel is protected by an 8' cyclone fence that has a padlock for security.  The vessel has a flash valve that prohibits a ruptured line or valve from emptying the vessel.

Approximately 200 feet of 2" service line connected the pressure vessel to the process building.  The first 100 fe

et of the service line is underground.  The service line is equipped with an emergency trip valve, a 2" gate valve, an electronic flow valve, and a manual 1" ball valve.

40 CFR 68.155(c)    The Worst-Case Release Scenario(s) and the Alternative Release
                        Scenario(s), Including Administrative Controls and Mitigation
                        Measures to Limit the Distance for Each Reported Scenario

Under the Risk Management Program, an offsite consequence analysis is required for an accidental release of a regulated substance.  In LPI's case, anhydrous ammonia is the regulated substance.  Modeling of a worst-case release scenario and an alternative release scenario for anhydrous ammonia are required for offsite consequence analysis under Program 3.

EPA defined a worst-case release as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to a specified endpoint.  The largest quantity should be determined taking into account administrative controls that limit the quantity of a substance that can be stored or processed in a vessel or pipe at any one time, or alternatively, procedures that occasionally allow the vessel or pipe to store larger than usual quantities.
Endpoint concentration for ammonia release was established by EPA to be 0.14 mg/L or 200 ppm by mass (40 CFR Part 68, Appendix A).

EPA defines the alternative release scenario to be any release that is more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario and that reaches an endpoint offsite.
The movement and dispersion of a regulated substance that is accidentally released to the atmosphere can be predicted by using EPA lookup tables tabulated in an EPA publication titled "Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis, April 1999 (OCGA)" or by using computer models.

The EPA lookup table method is straight forward and therefore is expected to be more conservative.  The results obtained using

the EPA lookup tables tend to overestimate the distance to endpoints.  Computer models, on the other hand, accounts for many site-specific factors will yield a less conservative estimate of offsite consequence than the EPA lookup tables.

A computer model named ALOHA (Area Locations of Hazardous Atmosphere) Version 5.4 (released in 2007) was used to predict the footprints of a worst-case release scenario and an alternative release scenario at the LPI facility.  The ALOHA computer model predicts the dispersion of anhydrous ammonia downwind from the release source, taking into consideration the physical characteristics of the anhydrous ammonia, the physical characteristics of the site, weather conditions, and the circumstance of the release.

The worst-case scenario for the LPI Ammonia Process for is the loss of 125,000 pounds of pressurized anhydrous ammonia representing a complete failure of the pressure vessel.  The entire content of the pressure vessel is released to the atmosphere within 10 minutes resulting in a release rate of 12,500 lbs/min.  Modeling results show that the worst-case scenario would have an offsite toxic endpoint of 2.5 miles.

The alternative release scenario selected for the LPI Ammonia Process for is the release of 125,000 pounds of pressurized anhydrous ammonia resulting from a failed connection on the pressure vessel.  The entire content of the pressure vessel is released to the atmosphere in 60 minutes resulting in a release rate of 2,083 lbs/min.  Modeling results show that the alternative release scenario would have an offsite toxic endpoint of 0.8 miles where the ammonia concentration drops below the level of concern of 0.14 mg/L or 200 ppm.

40 CFR 68.155(d)    The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-
                        Specific Prevention Steps

LPI has a Release Prevention Program in place to prevent accidental releases of hazardous materials at this facility.  The Release Prevention Program includes:

Proc

ess Safety Information (PSI)
Tetra has developed and kept current, working copies of PSI documentation including information pertaining to hazards of the process, the technology of the process and the equipment of the process.  All employees involve in the process has been trained in the operation of the process and all contractors will be given training before performing work in the process area.  The PSI will enable the employees and contractors of LPI to identify and understand the hazards posted by the process involving anhydrous ammonia.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
LPI is committed to performing PHA to identify, evaluate, and control hazards associated with plant operations.  The PHA is to analyze the potential mishaps, identify the mishaps that could occur, analyze the likelihood that mishaps will occur, evaluate the consequence of these mishaps, and analyzed the likelihood that safety systems, mitigation systems, and emergency systems will function properly to eliminate or reduce the consequences of a mishap.

The PHA will be updated at least every five (5) years to assure that the PHA is consistent with the current process.

Operating Procedures (OPs)
Tetra is committed to the development of OPs to assure safe work practices are maintained.  The OPs are reviewed regularly and will be updated as required.

Training
LPI is committed to provide its employees with comprehensive training to assure that the work force can perform their duties safely, efficiently, and effectively.

Mechanical Integrity (MI)
LPI has developed a written program of maintaining the MI of process equipment.  The MI program includes pressure vessel, storage tanks, piping systems and ancillary equipment, relief and vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance procedures are developed or promulgated by equipment vendors, federal or state regulations, or industry codes.

Incident Investigation
The current LPI Emergency Ammonia Release Response Pl

an is a component of the Incident Investigation process.  Incident reporting procedures are well defined.  Responsibilities, titles, and phone numbers are given in a highly readable document.

Compliance Audit
A compliance audit of the LPI facility will be conducted at least every three (3) years to evaluate compliance with the release prevention program (RPP).  The audit team will include at least one person knowledgeable in audit skills and techniques and team consists of team members with appropriate technical expertise.

Management of Change (MOC)
LPI has developed a MOC system to ensure that changes at the ammonia process will not result in undetected unsafe situations and employees will be aware of all changes and their implications.  LPI's MOC system includes the following considerations before any changes take place:
-    The authorization requirements for the change.
-    The technical basis for the proposed change.
-    The impact of the change on health and safety.
-    The necessary time for the change.
-    Required modification to Operating Procedures.
After changes are made, all employees will be informed about the change and training will be provided to the employees prior to startup of the modified process.  In addition, the PSI and OPs will be updated to reflect the changes made.

Pre-Startup Review (PSR)
When change to the process is significant enough to require a change in safety information under the MOC, LPI will conduct a PSR.  The PSR Team Leader will develop a checklist and assemble team of key personnel to go over every element on the checklist during the PSR.  All PSR team members will be knowledgeable about the process and trained in the area of chance.

Contractors
LPI will develop and implement safe work practices to control the entrance, presence and exit of contract employees in the plant.  It is LPI's policy to select safe contractors, provide appropriate safety related information to contractors, develop safe work practices related to contractors

and periodically evaluate contractors.

LPI will inform contractors of the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to the contractors work and the process.  LPI will also explain to contractor the applicable provisions of TetraAA?s emergency response plan.

Employee Participation
LPI is committed to involving employees and their representatives on the conduct and development of PHA and on the development of the other elements of plant safety, process safety management, and risk management planning.  LPI encourages employees to read, review, and provide comments on all RMP/PSM documents.

Hot Work Permit
Hot work is defined as work that could generate a flame, intense heat, or sparks as a result of electric or gas welding, cutting, blazing, abrasions or similar operations.  A permit is required when hot work is to be conducted in the LPI plant.

40 CFR 68.155(e)    Five-Year Accident History

The five-year accident history involves an examination of the effects of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the five year prior to the submission of a Risk Management Program.  The five-year accident history covers:

A release of anhydrous ammonia from the facility that caused at least one of
   the following:

   1.  Onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (40 CFR Part 68.42(a)); or
   2.  Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, 
       evacuations, or sheltering in place (40 CFR Part 68.42(a)).

The LPI Ammonia Process has had no releases that caused death, injuries, property damages, or environmental damage either on or off site since the startup of the Ammonia Process.

40 CFR 68.155(f)    The Emergency Response Program

LPI has a thorough detailed Emergency Ammonia Release Response Plan designated specifically for an ammonia release from the Ammonia Process.  The plan will be reviewed with response organizations and others.

40 CFR 68.155(g)    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

LPI will follow up
on all of the recommendations in the Risk Management Program revalidation in a timely manner.
